title: Turquoise seas, infinity pools and rooms with no walls: Why you're sure to have a blast on the volcanic island of St Lucia
text:
176 shares 1
View
comments
There is never a dull moment on the volcanic island of St Lucia, which lies north-west of Barbados between St Vincent and Martinique.
It’s very hilly and green, as you notice on the drive from the airport to the spectacular Anse Chastanet and Jade Mountain resorts.
On the way to our room we went past one where there was a swing which looked across the woods to the sea and there was a tree growing through the bathroom. Another room was full of giant canvases painted by a German artist.
SAX APPEAL: Penny with saxophone player Rob on the Jazzy B cruise
And that was one part of the resort. All quirky and idiosyncratic. The other part is called Jade Mountain, and it’s like something out of a James Bond film, with bright glass sculptures atop towering pinnacles of granite.
The rooms are open on two sides and your view is of the majestic Pitons rising from the turquoise sea on one side, while the rainforest rolls to the beach on the other.
Talk about the wow factor.
Normally, the idea of an open room (and for room, read whopping great Chelsea flat) would fill me with horror.
The double threat of mosquitoes and voyeurism would have me covered in netting and hiding behind a very large palm.

'It was a mixture of Cocoon, Fawlty Towers and Benidorm':... Heated open-air pools, champagne receptions and volcanic... 176 shares But neither was a problem and the only issue was whether to cool off in the infinity pool or in the exquisite shower.
At the beach restaurant, we gazed in awe at the two giant volcanic plugs rising from the sea... the Gros Piton (the big one) and the Petit Piton (the little one).
Derek Walcott, the famous St Lucian poet, described the larger volcanic plug thus: ‘In the midst of the sea is a horned island/ with deep green harbours.’
Wow factor: 'The rooms are open on two sides and your view is of the majestic Pitons rising from the turquoise sea on one side, while the rainforest rolls to the beach on the other'
The depth of the ‘harbours’ makes this among the finest places in the world for diving: there’s a vast array of marine life just yards from the beach because of the steep underwater cliff and coral reef.
One day, a man called Meno – who described himself as Father Nature – took us on a walk through the rainforest pointing out everything from the mimosa (‘The sensitive plant. You touch the leaves, they close up – my grandmother used to make tea with it as a cure for constipation’) to a leaf that stains your fingers bright red (‘they used it for dyeing clothes and nothing takes it out’).
He spotted green herons and tiny humming birds, and showed us how to open a coconut without spilling the milk, to pick an out-of-reach tangerine using a forked branch, and how to play a game involving sucked cocoa beans. I lost.
He also took the precaution of grabbing a couple of bin- liners from the kitchen before we set out and when the heavens suddenly opened, made a hole in the bottom and gave me a rudimentary mackintosh. Cracking.
Janice, our waitress at lunch, commented on it. ‘Nice coat. Is it one of those made-to-measure jobs from Paris?’
One afternoon we took a cruise on the yacht Serenity with Captain Kerwin and Theofor, who threw out a line to see whether any fish would bite. There were six of us on the boat and we laughed so much I had to have an extra rib put in.
That rum punch was strong. Or maybe it was the strong sea breeze which had us belting north along the coast towards the capital, Castries.
One evening a week, you can go on the three-hour Jazzy B Cruise while listening to a sax master called Rob with hair like a badly disordered pineapple.
It was all very chilled until we spotted a whopping pod of dolphins and suddenly everyone was talking to each other and bonding as the dolphins leapt and twirled through the big blue. Captain Garfield told us that sometimes they see pods of more than a hundred. ‘The sea looks like it’s boiling,’ he observed.
The next day, we had a look round our local town, Soufrière, which was important in the 18th Century because of the sulphur deposited by the island’s warm springs, which come from the local volcano.
The name Soufrière actually means ‘sulphur mine’. We loitered in the warm mineral baths, where allegedly, Napoleon’s wife Josephine would swim.
‘Sulphur, so good,’ I quipped.
